newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovakia, Russia to sign free trade treaty in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Slovakia, Russia to sign free trade treaty in 1997.

text.p: Slovakia, in a bid to curb its burgeoning trade deficit, expects to sign a free-trade agreement with Russia by the end of next year, Finance Minister Sergej Kozlik said on Saturday.

"We expect to complete the final text of the treaty by the end of June next year, so that it can be signed at a meeting of prime ministers later in 1997," Kozlik told a news conference after three days of talks between Russian and Slovak officials in Bratislava.

"It's a big issue which we have to observe from a wider context and not only from an economic point of view," said Russian Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Babichev, who led the Russian side at the negotiations.
Neither official would comment on the pace, or extent to which trade will be liberalised.
"So far only a basic framework agreement has been agreed upon, and now experts from both countries will work out concrete details of the treaty," Kozlik said.

In the first nine months of this year Slovakia's trade deficit with Moscow totalled 35.4 billion slovak crown ($1.15 billion). The entire Slovak trade gap totalled 37.17 billion crowns over the same period.
Kozlik said the two countries also reached an agreement on cooperation between their central banks, which should help facilitate financial transactions related to mutual trade.
Slovakia and Russia also signed several cooperation agreements.
Russia is Slovakia's sole crude oil and natural gas supplier and major raw materials source.
Kozlik also urged Slovak commercial banks to participate more actively in financing trade with Moscow.

"Our largest banks, such VUB bank for example, should open branches in Russia and create joint banking institutions with Russian banks to help solve payment problems for our mutual trade," Kozlik said, without elaborating further. ($1=30.79 Slovak Crown)
